newsitem.title: USA: Bausch & Lomb Q4 eyewear revenues down.
newsitem.headline: Bausch & Lomb Q4 eyewear revenues down.

text.p: Bausch & Lomb Inc said Tuesday it suffered a sharp decline in sunglass sales during the 1996 fourth quarter.
Revenues in the eyewear segment, which includes the sunglass and thin film coating businesses, were down 21 percent in the quarter from a year earlier, it said.
The decline was due primarily to the cancelation of orders from its largest sunglass customer, Sunglass Hut International Inc, B&L said.
For the full year 1996, sales from continuing product lines in the eyewear segment fell seven percent from 1995.

In the vision care segment, which consists of contact lens and lens care products, revenues for the fourth quarter were up seven percent from a year earlier, B&L said. Full year vision care sales rose seven percent from 1995.

For the 1996 fourth quarter, the pharmaceutical sector posted a one percent gain in sales, despite the negative impact of German currency swings and a significant slowdown in the German retail pharmaceutical market, the company said.
B&L said it posted a 10 percent net sales gain from continuing businesses in its healthcare segment in the fourth quarter.

Overall, it posted net sales from ongoing businesses of $430.0 million for the quarter, down one percent from $432.6 million a year earlier. The 1996 figure excludes $4.7 million in revenues from the dental implant business divested in mid-November. The 1995 figure excludes $7.3 million in dental implant sales, and $15.2 million in sales from the Oral Care Division, divested in September 1996.
Including revenues from these divested businesses, revenues in the 1996 fourth quarter were $434.8 million, down four percent from $455.1 million in net sales recorded in the same quarter of 1995.
On a net basis, Rochester, N.Y.-based Bausch & Lomb posted earnings of $15.8 million or $0.29 a share in the fourth quarter, compared to a net loss of $3.3 million or $0.04 a share a year earlier.
The company said changes in foreign exchange rates hurt 1996 results.
